summary: Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is a cancer that develops in the lymph system, a part of the immune system. It is characterized by the presence of multinucleated Reed–Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes and affects a subgroup of white blood cells called lymphocytes. It is one of the main types of lymphoma, distinct from non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
risk_factors: Age (most common in early adulthood and late adulthood)
Large number of involved nodal sites
symptoms: Painless, swollen lymph nodes (neck, underarm, groin)
Hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of both liver and spleen)
diagnosis: Lymph node biopsy (excision biopsy with microscopic examination)
Blood tests (complete blood count, blood chemistry studies, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) test, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) test)
Imaging tests (CT scan, PET scan, MRI scan, gallium scan)
treatments: Radiation therapy (external beam radiation therapy, mantle field radiation, inverted-Y field radiation, total nodal irradiation)
Targeted therapy (e.g., brentuximab vedotin, nivolumab, pembrolizumab)
